Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploration of THz Backscattering as a Side-channel in Computer Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project looks into a new side channel information that attackers can use to learn a computer chip design. This is important for advancing the science for understanding what vulnerabilities there are from this side channel.

A new side-channel, which is called Terahertz-frequency (THz) backscattering, is the focus of this project. A computer system directly emanates virtually no THz-frequency signals. Instead, a THz signal is transmitted toward the desired part of the targeted system and is reflected back. The signal contains information about the activity in the targeted part of the system because the signal's reflection depends on the impedance of the material it reflects from, so the reflected signal is modulated by the switching state of any transistors that are in the target area (or connected to metal wires that are in the target area) of the incoming THz beam. The project will construct the first-ever measurement testbed for THz backscattering side-channels, use this testbed to evaluate the key properties of THz back-scattering from system boards, chip pins, and circuitry within a chip, and characterize the advantages and disadvantages of THz back-scattering for various use scenarios, e.g. as a "signature" of a specific chip, as a way of validating a chip's activity against a "known good" reference, as a potential threat (when used for side channel attacks), etc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An analog side-channel is a way to obtain information about computation within a computer system by observing some physical side-effect of that computation, e.g. by measuring the system’s power consumption, radio-frequency emanations, the acoustic signals it emanates, etc. This project was an initial investigation of the new side-channel, which we call Terahertz-Frequency (THz) backscattering. Compared to existing analog side channels, the THz backscattering side channel is unique in that that computer system emanates virtually no THz signals. Instead, the side channel is formed by 1) transmitting a THz signal towards the desired part of the target system and 2) observing the signal reflected (back-scattered) from the target system. We have found that this back-scattered signal contains information about the electronic activity within the targeted system, so it exfiltrates information about the computation within that system.

The key results of this project were to construct the first-ever measurement testbed for THz backscattering side-channels, use this testbed to evaluate the key properties of THz back-scattering from system boards, chip pins, and circuitry within a chip, and provide initial characterization of this new side channel as a potential threat (when used for side-channel attacks) and as a way of improving security of the target system by using the back-scattered signal as a “signature" of a specific chip or as a way to detect that the chip is different from what it purports to be.

The broader impact of this work includes laying the foundation for potential future improvements in cyber-security, as well as educating several students in this inherently multi-disciplinary problem domain, giving them a unique skill-set and expertise, as well as experience in how to approach multi-disciplinary research in general.
